fields.Problem: I’m passionate about using AI to empower small and local businesses, a sector that’s often overlooked because it doesn’t seem “high-tech” on the surface. My goal is to build tools that are intuitive, multilingual, and designed around their real workflows, rather than repurposed from enterprise software. Helping these businesses go digital isn’t just impactful — it’s an open frontier where thoughtful innovation can create outsized value.

fields.Problem:
Energy exploration sector (oil, gas, geothermal, CCUS, hydrogen, etc.) have siloed approach between the participating domains like drilling, reservoir and production engineering. However, an interactive, interdependent, and transparent approach is necessary to reduce risks and increasing operational efficiency and production lifetime. This can be accomplished by using Agentic AI framework that is orchestrated by a domain specific LLM for planning and decision making workflows.

This framework can be extended to any other domain that must communicate with multiple digital twins or expertises for a cohesive decision making process. Nevertheless, I'm not married to this idea and rather use it as a starting point and pivot if and when necessary during the sprint.

fields.Favorite startup: Canva's is a recent one I learned about and resonate with. Melanie didn't start as a tech CEO or had tech background, as a teacher at a university she was experiencing first-hand how much overcomplexity and friction existed in the current landscape of design tools, limiting their access. She was aware of the pain and envisioned an experience where designing was quick, easy and accessible. Started with a simple tool that took off which opened up the door to further impact. With no connections, no technical background and no flashy titles as Ex-Something and away of Silicon Valley's hub, she landed investment from Bill Tai because her vision was clear. She wanted Canva to do for design what Google did for search. Instead of going for the obvious pool of user's that Adobe was already serving Canva targeted everyone else, tapping into a massive under-served market. Simple product with drag-and-drop and freemium model destroyed any potential barriers for user's engagement. With millions of users and a valuation peaking at 40 billion she became one of the youngest self-made billionaires without following the well-walked noisy path many choose to follow. What I truly admire most is how truly impact driven the founders have been by pleading donating 30% of the company's value to social impact causes.

fields.Problem: I want to solve the problem of C-suite executives drowning in noise by building a specialized AI model that acts like a role-aware research analyst. Starting with crypto — where I’ve worked as a research analyst and know the highest-signal data sources — the model ingests on-chain activity, ETF flows, governance proposals, and regulatory updates, then delivers a five-minute, role-specific brief: what happened, why it matters for their function, and one action to consider. The biggest thing I’ve learned is that decision-makers don’t need more data — they need the right data, presented frictionlessly, so they can act with confidence. This product systematically improves as we interview executives, refine prompts, and tune outputs, then scales across other high-velocity information industries (AI, fintech, biotech) using the same playbook. Upsells include custom-trained models for even more precise insight targeting, but the core value is consolidating what’s already out there into clear, actionable takeaways. This hits all the Lab’s criteria: prosumer focus, AI as the value engine, product-led viral growth through Slack/Teams sharing, and direct monetization via per-seat subscriptions.

fields.Problem: The problem I want to solve is loneliness, the quiet epidemic of our hyperconnected world. I believe the next trillion-dollar opportunity lies in rethinking how humans and machines coexist emotionally. My vision is to create a proactive AI companion that lives as an overlay on your devices. An extension of you that anticipates, interacts, and connects, not just responds. Over time, these companions will start talking to each other, forming a new kind of social operating system, one that transcends apps entirely and redefines digital presence itself.

fields.Favorite startup: Canva's is a recent one I learned about and resonate with. Melanie didn't start as a tech CEO or had tech background, as a teacher at a university she was experiencing first-hand how much overcomplexity and friction existed in the current landscape of design tools, limiting their access. She was aware of the pain and envisioned an experience where designing was quick, easy and accessible. Started with a simple tool that took off which opened up the door to further impact. With no connections, no technical background and no flashy titles as Ex-Something and away of Silicon Valley's hub, she landed investment from Bill Tai because her vision was clear. She wanted Canva to do for design what Google did for search. Instead of going for the obvious pool of user's that Adobe was already serving Canva targeted everyone else, tapping into a massive under-served market. Simple product with drag-and-drop and freemium model destroyed any potential barriers for user's engagement. With millions of users and a valuation peaking at 40 billion she became one of the youngest self-made billionaires without following the well-walked noisy path many choose to follow. What I truly admire most is how truly impact driven the founders have been by pleading donating 30% of the company's value to social impact causes.

fields.Favorite startup: My favorite story is the one I’m still part of — Rarible. We came up with the idea almost seven years ago, before anyone knew what “NFT” meant. There were four of us, sitting in a restaurant, brainstorming. A year later, we had over a million users, and major companies and celebrities were reaching out to us. We went from four people to over 120, through many ups and downs. What I value most is the experience — learning, adapting, and staying connected to the consumer market. I’ve worn every hat: grew our social media from zero to 100k followers (now close to a million), came up with the company name, ran hundreds of experiments, and worked with people around the world. The world keeps changing, and I want to build something that truly makes a positive impact on human life.

fields.Problem:
I want to solve the problem of how talent is measured and discovered.

Resumes and job titles say little about a person’s real ability, especially for self-taught developers and students from non-traditional paths, like those in the 42 network. AI can change that.

By turning job descriptions into personalized, skill-based challenges, AI can evaluate what candidates can do, not just what they claim to have done. It can fairly match people to opportunities based on performance, context, and potential, not credentials.

My goal is to use AI to make skills the universal language of hiring, so that opportunity depends on capability, not background.

That’s what I’m building with After-42 using AI agents to translate jobs into challenges, and challenges into proof of skill.
fields.Skills:
I’m a full-stack and agentic developer passionate about building AI-driven systems that can reason, act, and adapt. I develop modern, production-grade web applications using tools like Mastra.ai, Next.js, TypeScript, Drizzle ORM, and PostgreSQL/Turso, with a focus on clean architecture and scalability.

I’m also deeply experienced in Single Page Application (SPA) design and client-side optimization, creating seamless, fast, and responsive user experiences that merge traditional engineering precision with next-generation AI capabilities.

I’m currently working on After-42, an AI-powered hiring marketplace built exclusively for students of the 42 network. It transforms job offers into custom technical challenges, helping companies assess real skills instead of resumes. The goal is to make skills, not CV's, the currency of hiring.

Even though they’re French, they had an international mindset from day one, proving you don’t need to start in Silicon Valley to build a global success.
